key_points: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton and his wife traveled to Utah during severe winter storms in Texas.
The trip's timing and purpose were defended by Paxton's campaign spokesperson, stating it occurred after power was largely restored in Texas.
Paxton went to Utah to meet with the Utah Attorney General to discuss legal matters and a Google lawsuit.
This incident marks Paxton as the second high-profile Republican to leave Texas amid the winter crisis, following Sen. Ted Cruz's trip to Cancun.
Sen. Ted Cruz admitted his trip was a mistake upon returning, amid criticism for leaving during the state's emergency.
Cruz's role as a federal official differs from Paxton's state responsibilities, which include aspects of disaster response.
Democratic officials and figures criticized Paxton and Cruz for their actions during the crisis.
Texas faced a severe shortage of power and water, impacting millions of residents.
8.6 million people were still experiencing water disruptions as of Monday evening.
The winter storm's aftermath in Texas may require weeks or months for full recovery.
spokespersons: Ian Prior (Campaign Spokesperson for Ken Paxton)
Gary Rasp (Media Specialist, Texas Commission on Environmental Quality)
